title: 105_hr3497
content: The "Individual Investment Account Act of 1998" establishes Individual Investment Accounts under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Individual Investment Account Act of 1998 allows individuals to deduct cash payments made to an individual investment account established for their benefit. An individual investment account is a trust created in the U.S. for the exclusive benefit of an individual, meeting specific requirements. The Individual Investment Account Act of 1998 allows individuals to deduct cash payments made to a trust in the U.S. for their exclusive benefit, with specific requirements for the trust's governing instrument and trustee qualifications. The Individual Investment Account Act of 1998 allows individuals to deduct cash payments made to a trust in the U.S. for their exclusive benefit, with specific requirements for the trust's governing instrument and trustee qualifications. The trust assets must not be invested in collectibles and should not be commingled with other property except in a common trust fund or common investment fund. Contributions are deemed made on the last day of the taxable year if made on account of that year and before the deadline for filing the tax return. The Individual Investment Account Act of 1998 allows individuals to deduct cash payments made to a trust in the U.S. for their exclusive benefit. Contributions are considered made on the last day of the taxable year before the deadline for filing the tax return. Distributions from an individual investment account are generally included in gross income unless part of a qualified 1st-time homebuyer distribution. "A qualified 1st-time homebuyer distribution is a payment received by an individual from an individual investment account, used within 120 days for qualified acquisition costs for a principal residence." "A qualified 1st-time homebuyer distribution allows individuals to use funds from an investment account for qualified acquisition costs on a principal residence. The total amount for such distributions cannot exceed $20,000, and the basis of the residence is reduced by the distribution amount. Additionally, account transfers incident to divorce are permitted." The transfer of an individual's interest in an individual investment account to a former spouse under a divorce decree is not considered a taxable transfer. The interest at the time of the transfer becomes the spouse's account. Individual investment account transferred to a former spouse under a divorce decree is not taxable. The account is treated as maintained for the benefit of the spouse and is exempt from taxation unless it no longer qualifies as an individual investment account. Individual investment accounts are subject to taxes under section 511 if the individual engages in prohibited transactions, causing the account to lose its exemption status. Individual investment accounts may lose their exemption status if they cease to be individual investment accounts at the beginning of a taxable year. In such cases, it is treated as if all assets in the account were distributed on that day. "If an individual uses an individual investment account as security for a loan during a taxable year, the portion used is treated as distributed to that individual. Rollover contributions are not subject to subsection (c)(1) for amounts paid or distributed from the account." Individual investment account payments or distributions can be transferred to another account for the same individual within 60 days. Cost-of-Living Adjustment increases the $20,000 amount annually after 1998. The dollar amount in subsection (c)(2)(B) is increased annually based on the cost-of-living adjustment determined for the calendar year. If the increased amount is not a multiple of $10, it will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $10. The dollar amount in subsection (c)(2)(B) is increased annually based on the cost-of-living adjustment determined for the calendar year. If the amount is not a multiple of $10, it will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $10. Custodial accounts are treated as trusts if held by a bank or another entity meeting specific criteria. The trustee of an individual investment account must report to the Secretary and the account holder on contributions, distributions, and other relevant matters as required by regulations. Reports must be filed and furnished in a timely manner. The trustee of an individual investment account must report to the Secretary on contributions and distributions as required by regulations. Deductions allowed in arriving at adjusted gross income include individual investment account contributions. Individual investment accounts are exempt from estate tax. Individual investment accounts are exempt from estate tax under section 222. Additionally, the trustee must report contributions and distributions to the Secretary. "Individual investment accounts are exempt from estate tax under section 222. The trustee must report contributions and distributions to the Secretary. SEC. 2046 pertains to individual investment accounts." Individual investment accounts are excluded from the gross estate value and are exempt from estate tax. Section 1014 does not apply to these accounts. A special rule exempts individuals from tax on prohibited transactions related to their individual investment accounts. Individual investment accounts are exempt from estate tax and prohibited transactions related to these accounts are also exempt from tax under certain conditions. Individual investment accounts, as described in section 222(b), are now included in the tax code. Failure to provide reports on these accounts is subject to penalties under section 6693(a) of the Code. The tax code now includes individual investment accounts under section 222(b). Section 1016(a) is amended to adjust the basis of a residence acquired with funds from such accounts. The tax code now includes individual investment accounts for the acquisition of a residence. Section 222 is amended, and clerical amendments are made to the table of sections. Section 222 of the tax code is amended to include individual investment accounts for acquiring a residence. Section 2046 and 2047 are added to the table of sections. The amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1997.
